values.description:
Changes are:

  - Minor description updates in sdf 1.4.
  - Renaming(deprecating) `cfm_damping` parameter in sdf 1.4 to  `implicit_spring_damper` parameter (conversion unit test added).
`gear_ratio` and `reference_body`.

Needed by [gazebo pull request #735](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/735/create-spring-damper-in-joints-issue-845/diff).
values.title: rename cfm_damping --> implicit_spring_damper

summary.raw:
Changes are:

  - Minor description updates in sdf 1.4.
  - Renaming(deprecating) `cfm_damping` parameter in sdf 1.4 to  `implicit_spring_damper` parameter (conversion unit test added).
`gear_ratio` and `reference_body`.

Needed by [gazebo pull request #735](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/735/create-spring-damper-in-joints-issue-845/diff).
summary.html:
Changes are:

  • Minor description updates in sdf 1.4.
  • Renaming(deprecating) cfm_damping parameter in sdf 1.4 to implicit_spring_damper parameter (conversion unit test added). gear_ratio and reference_body.

Needed by gazebo pull request #735.

values.description:
Use GNUInstallDirs instead of hardcore values for directories.

Similar migration [was done for gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/676/migrate-unix-directories-to-use/diff), and the [previous reasons](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo-release/issue/32/use-gnuinstalldirs-to-provide-file) also apply here.
values.title: Support for GNUInstallDirs

summary.raw:
Use GNUInstallDirs instead of hardcore values for directories.

summary.html:
Use GNUInstallDirs instead of hardcore values for directories.

Similar migration was done for gazebo, and the previous reasons also apply here.

values.description:
Compilation fails on osx 10.9, due to a lack of certain tr1 header files (#36), which are referenced by gtest. Updating to gtest 1.7.0 fixes the build.

Also fixed some compiler warnings on osx by using `std::isfinite()` instead of `finite()`, since `finite()` is now deprecated.
values.title: Update gtest to 1.7.0 to fix osx 10.9 build (#36)

summary.raw:
Compilation fails on osx 10.9, due to a lack of certain tr1 header files (#36), which are referenced by gtest. Updating to gtest 1.7.0 fixes the build.

Also fixed some compiler warnings on osx by using `std::isfinite()` instead of `finite()`, since `finite()` is now deprecated.
summary.html:
Compilation fails on osx 10.9, due to a lack of certain tr1 header files (#36), which are referenced by gtest. Updating to gtest 1.7.0 fixes the build.

Also fixed some compiler warnings on osx by using std::isfinite() instead of finite(), since finite() is now deprecated.

Fixes for non real errors in [saucy cppcheck](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-default-devel-saucy-amd64/3/cppcheckResult/?)

values.description:
There was a problem with the pattern for exclusion of the full src/urdf directory. After investigate it a bit, seems like it is not trivial to remove a whole directory with subdirectories. I end up removing totally the suppression since there are no warnings.

The other workaround is when using --suppress=missingIncludeSystem with -j greater than 1. I added the description in the script.
values.title: Two workarounds for final issues with cppcheck

summary.raw:
There was a problem with the pattern for exclusion of the full src/urdf directory. After investigate it a bit, seems like it is not trivial to remove a whole directory with subdirectories. I end up removing totally the suppression since there are no warnings.

The other workaround is when using --suppress=missingIncludeSystem with -j greater than 1. I added the description in the script.
summary.html:
There was a problem with the pattern for exclusion of the full src/urdf directory. After investigate it a bit, seems like it is not trivial to remove a whole directory with subdirectories. I end up removing totally the suppression since there are no warnings.

The other workaround is when using --suppress=missingIncludeSystem with -j greater than 1. I added the description in the script.

values.description:
Remove of sdformat embedded copy of URDF and use the one in the system. Some notes:

* We should generate and upload packages for urdfdom and console_bridge first to our repo.
* If someone is using ROS and source setup.sh before compiling sdformat (or any software which use urdfdom or console_bridge), ROS copies will be used instead of system ones.

Running the ABI/API checker now, I'll update the pull request as soon as it is ready.
values.title: Use external URDF parser

summary.raw:
Remove of sdformat embedded copy of URDF and use the one in the system. Some notes:

* We should generate and upload packages for urdfdom and console_bridge first to our repo.
* If someone is using ROS and source setup.sh before compiling sdformat (or any software which use urdfdom or console_bridge), ROS copies will be used instead of system ones.

Running the ABI/API checker now, I'll update the pull request as soon as it is ready.
summary.html:
Remove of sdformat embedded copy of URDF and use the one in the system. Some notes:

  • We should generate and upload packages for urdfdom and console_bridge first to our repo.
  • If someone is using ROS and source setup.sh before compiling sdformat (or any software which use urdfdom or console_bridge), ROS copies will be used instead of system ones.

Running the ABI/API checker now, I'll update the pull request as soon as it is ready.

values.description:
Motivation in issue #29.

My solution tries not to be intrusive into the embedded urdf code (so it can easily be replaced). I have transformed all urdf files we use of it into a static library, use ```visibility=hidden``` for it and after add it as part of libsdformat.

Symbols can be checked using ```nm -D``` or ```objdump -T```. 

The [ABI check report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/16/API_ABI_report/?) complains about missing symbols, but only related to boost. Looks weird to me.

@po1 it would be nice if you can give a try and confirm that this fix (or not) your problem.
values.title: Do not export urdf symbols in sdformat library (-> default)

summary.raw:
Motivation in issue #29.

My solution tries not to be intrusive into the embedded urdf code (so it can easily be replaced). I have transformed all urdf files we use of it into a static library, use ```visibility=hidden``` for it and after add it as part of libsdformat.

Symbols can be checked using ```nm -D``` or ```objdump -T```. 

The [ABI check report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/16/API_ABI_report/?) complains about missing symbols, but only related to boost. Looks weird to me.

@po1 it would be nice if you can give a try and confirm that this fix (or not) your problem.
summary.html:
Motivation in issue #29.

My solution tries not to be intrusive into the embedded urdf code (so it can easily be replaced). I have transformed all urdf files we use of it into a static library, use visibility=hidden for it and after add it as part of libsdformat.

Symbols can be checked using nm -D or objdump -T.

The ABI check report complains about missing symbols, but only related to boost. Looks weird to me.

@po1 it would be nice if you can give a try and confirm that this fix (or not) your problem.

values.description:
Motivation in issue #29.

This implementation came from pull request #74 and the need of keep the ABI stable while hidden urdf symbols.

In this case I've changed the priority to don't change imported urdf code by ABI stability, so the current implementation go URDF class by URDF class defining hidden attribute for them. I would prefer the approach in pull request #74, but we can go this until new sdformat2 appear. 

The [ABI/API report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/20/) looks sane.

@po1 if you can confirm that this approach works for your case, perfect.
values.title: Do not export urdf symbols in sdformat 1.4 (-> sdf_1.4)

summary.raw:
Motivation in issue #29.

This implementation came from pull request #74 and the need of keep the ABI stable while hidden urdf symbols.

In this case I've changed the priority to don't change imported urdf code by ABI stability, so the current implementation go URDF class by URDF class defining hidden attribute for them. I would prefer the approach in pull request #74, but we can go this until new sdformat2 appear. 

The [ABI/API report](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/20/) looks sane.

@po1 if you can confirm that this approach works for your case, perfect.
summary.html:
Motivation in issue #29.

This implementation came from pull request #74 and the need of keep the ABI stable while hidden urdf symbols.

In this case I've changed the priority to don't change imported urdf code by ABI stability, so the current implementation go URDF class by URDF class defining hidden attribute for them. I would prefer the approach in pull request #74, but we can go this until new sdformat2 appear.

The ABI/API report looks sane.

@po1 if you can confirm that this approach works for your case, perfect.

values.description:
Explicit declaration of enabled symbol visibility for classes and functions of the sdformat package and define a hidden visibility by default.

It will [break ABI compatibility](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/21/API_ABI_report/?) so targeting to default.

It was [suggested](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/75/do-not-export-urdf-symbols-in-sdformat-14/diff#comment-829134) by @thomas_moulard.
values.title: Initial work on support visibility hidden by default (-> default)

summary.raw:
Explicit declaration of enabled symbol visibility for classes and functions of the sdformat package and define a hidden visibility by default.

It will [break ABI compatibility](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/21/API_ABI_report/?) so targeting to default.

It was [suggested](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/75/do-not-export-urdf-symbols-in-sdformat-14/diff#comment-829134) by @thomas_moulard.
summary.html:
Explicit declaration of enabled symbol visibility for classes and functions of the sdformat package and define a hidden visibility by default.

It will break ABI compatibility so targeting to default.

It was suggested by @thomas_moulard.

summary.html:

values.description:
For some reason, gazebo has historically interpreted the joint axis `<xyz>` value in the parent model frame. It would make more sense to use the child link frame, since the joint pose element for specifying the anchor location is interpreted relative to the child link frame. This is sdformat issue #43 and [gazebo issue 494](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/494).

This pull request adds a tag called `use_parent_model_frame` to the joint axis element. If true, it implies the legacy behavior (parent model frame) should be used. If false, then the child link frame should be used. This requires a bump to sdf 1.5, in order to use the Converter to provide legacy support. The converter will add the use_parent_model_frame tag with value true whenever converting version 1.4 models. For 1.5 models, the default value is false, so if the tag is omitted, the child link frame will be used.

I had to add a new `Converter::Add` function, so I added tests for it (and split the other Converter tests up a bit). I also added an `INTEGRATION_joint_axis_frame` test to verify that sdf 1.4 models would receive a value of true for `use_parent_model_frame` and sdf 1.5 models would receive a value of false.
values.title: SDF 1.5: add flag to fix joint axis frame #43 (gazebo issue 494)

summary.raw:
For some reason, gazebo has historically interpreted the joint axis `<xyz>` value in the parent model frame. It would make more sense to use the child link frame, since the joint pose element for specifying the anchor location is interpreted relative to the child link frame. This is sdformat issue #43 and [gazebo issue 494](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/494).

This pull request adds a tag called `use_parent_model_frame` to the joint axis element. If true, it implies the legacy behavior (parent model frame) should be used. If false, then the child link frame should be used. This requires a bump to sdf 1.5, in order to use the Converter to provide legacy support. The converter will add the use_parent_model_frame tag with value true whenever converting version 1.4 models. For 1.5 models, the default value is false, so if the tag is omitted, the child link frame will be used.

I had to add a new `Converter::Add` function, so I added tests for it (and split the other Converter tests up a bit). I also added an `INTEGRATION_joint_axis_frame` test to verify that sdf 1.4 models would receive a value of true for `use_parent_model_frame` and sdf 1.5 models would receive a value of false.
summary.html:
For some reason, gazebo has historically interpreted the joint axis <xyz> value in the parent model frame. It would make more sense to use the child link frame, since the joint pose element for specifying the anchor location is interpreted relative to the child link frame. This is sdformat issue #43 and gazebo issue 494.

This pull request adds a tag called use_parent_model_frame to the joint axis element. If true, it implies the legacy behavior (parent model frame) should be used. If false, then the child link frame should be used. This requires a bump to sdf 1.5, in order to use the Converter to provide legacy support. The converter will add the use_parent_model_frame tag with value true whenever converting version 1.4 models. For 1.5 models, the default value is false, so if the tag is omitted, the child link frame will be used.

I had to add a new Converter::Add function, so I added tests for it (and split the other Converter tests up a bit). I also added an INTEGRATION_joint_axis_frame test to verify that sdf 1.4 models would receive a value of true for use_parent_model_frame and sdf 1.5 models would receive a value of false.

values.description:
This is an update to pull request #86, which touches `src/parser_urdf.cc`.

I threw in a bug fix that prevented `gz sdf` from print documentation about a specific version of SDF. It's a small change to only source files that makes the `gz sdf` tool work properly.

UPDATE: retargeted by scpeters to sdf_1.5

values.description:
Long explanation in issue #51.

Short version: preserve the meaning of ```SDF_VERSION``` = protocol version but split the variable in two: one representing package version (```SDF_PKG_VERSION```) and another representing the protocol version (```SDF_PKG_VERSION```).
values.title: Implement SDF_PROTOCOL_VERSION (issue #51)

summary.raw:
Long explanation in issue #51.

Short version: preserve the meaning of ```SDF_VERSION``` = protocol version but split the variable in two: one representing package version (```SDF_PKG_VERSION```) and another representing the protocol version (```SDF_PKG_VERSION```).
summary.html:
Long explanation in issue #51.

Short version: preserve the meaning of SDF_VERSION = protocol version but split the variable in two: one representing package version (SDF_PKG_VERSION) and another representing the protocol version (SDF_PKG_VERSION).

values.description:
The pull request implements the generation and installation of xml schema files from sdf files.

For testing, I've imported 3 models of sdf:

* pendulum: an easy one
* turtlebot: medium complexity
* pr2: probably one of the largest out there. 

**Turtlebot test is currently failing**:  the turtlebot model is failing because there are `<include>` tags within a model, while I believe these are only acceptable for a world at the moment.

**PR2 test is currently failing**: *It doesn't like to have `/` characters in element text (i.e. `<script>Gazebo/Red</script>` in the material element). The pr2 test has four instances of this, which cause failures.*

Before merged, we must address this two failures in testing.

Thanks to @scpeters for the information about what is failing in the tests.
values.title: Implement generation of XML Schema files (issue #2)

summary.raw:
The pull request implements the generation and installation of xml schema files from sdf files.

For testing, I've imported 3 models of sdf:

* pendulum: an easy one
* turtlebot: medium complexity
* pr2: probably one of the largest out there. 

**Turtlebot test is currently failing**:  the turtlebot model is failing because there are `<include>` tags within a model, while I believe these are only acceptable for a world at the moment.

**PR2 test is currently failing**: *It doesn't like to have `/` characters in element text (i.e. `<script>Gazebo/Red</script>` in the material element). The pr2 test has four instances of this, which cause failures.*

Before merged, we must address this two failures in testing.

Thanks to @scpeters for the information about what is failing in the tests.
summary.html:
The pull request implements the generation and installation of xml schema files from sdf files.

For testing, I've imported 3 models of sdf:

  • pendulum: an easy one
  • turtlebot: medium complexity
  • pr2: probably one of the largest out there.

Turtlebot test is currently failing: the turtlebot model is failing because there are <include> tags within a model, while I believe these are only acceptable for a world at the moment.

PR2 test is currently failing: It doesn't like to have / characters in element text (i.e. <script>Gazebo/Red</script> in the material element). The pr2 test has four instances of this, which cause failures.

Before merged, we must address this two failures in testing.

Thanks to @scpeters for the information about what is failing in the tests.

values.description: The build has been [failing recently on osx homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/18/). This makes it [succeed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/19/).
values.title: Fix tinyxml linking on osx homebrew

summary.raw: The build has been [failing recently on osx homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/18/). This makes it [succeed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/19/).
summary.html: The build has been failing recently on osx homebrew. This makes it succeed.

values.description:
Start on a fix for https://github.com/PR2/pr2_common/issues/227 .

There's something wrong the parsing here, because the projector is showing up at a very strange angle, but it's a start. Feedback welcome.

![projector_angle.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/bgRG7y/images/1817482665-projector_angle.png)
values.title: Add RPYXYZ parser for projector pose

values.description: If the covert script could not be found, prefix the filename with the "toVersion".
values.title: Fix find convert script

summary.raw: If the covert script could not be found, prefix the filename with the "toVersion".
summary.html: If the covert script could not be found, prefix the filename with the "toVersion".

values.description:
This pull request adds a new tag to sdf `force_torque` sensor, to properly specify the measured wrench direction.
It also clarifies the meaning of the existing `frame` tag. 

For the related discussion, please check [gazebo issue 940](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/940/force-torque-sensor-forcetorquesensorcc) .
values.title: Add new tag measure_direction to force_torque sensor

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a new tag to sdf `force_torque` sensor, to properly specify the measured wrench direction.
It also clarifies the meaning of the existing `frame` tag. 

For the related discussion, please check [gazebo issue 940](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/940/force-torque-sensor-forcetorquesensorcc) .
summary.html:
This pull request adds a new tag to sdf force_torque sensor, to properly specify the measured wrench direction. It also clarifies the meaning of the existing frame tag.

For the related discussion, please check gazebo issue 940 .

values.description:
Bump sdformat patch number for development purposes

pull request #98 is causing test failures in gazebo's default branch if an old sdformat version is used. If we bump the patch number here then we can disable the failing test for sdformat 2.0.0, while letting it run for 2.0.1 and later.
values.title: Bump sdformat patch number for development purposes

summary.raw:
Bump sdformat patch number for development purposes

pull request #98 is causing test failures in gazebo's default branch if an old sdformat version is used. If we bump the patch number here then we can disable the failing test for sdformat 2.0.0, while letting it run for 2.0.1 and later.
summary.html:
Bump sdformat patch number for development purposes

pull request #98 is causing test failures in gazebo's default branch if an old sdformat version is used. If we bump the patch number here then we can disable the failing test for sdformat 2.0.0, while letting it run for 2.0.1 and later.

values.description:
Tinyxml does not have an installer on windows and seems easier to build an static copy of this library into sdformat. In fact, tinxyml was created with this goal as read in its own README.

Import version 2.6.2 and build only on windows.
values.title: Embed a copy of tinyxml for windows
